titleStmt.title: Ductile Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 refractory high entropy alloy with high specific strength

analytic.title: Ductile Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 refractory high entropy alloy with high specific strength

biblStruct.note: Received 15 December 2020 Received in revised form 23 January 2021 Accepted 25 January 2021

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Refractory high-entropy alloys Specific yield strength Deformation and fracture Solid solution strength Cross-slip of dislocations Microstructure

div.p: The ambient temperature brittleness and high density of refractory high entropy alloys (RHEAs) are the obstacles for their applications as structural materials. A novel ductile body-centered cubic Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 RHEA with high specific strength was developed. The tensile specific yield strength and fracture elongation of this alloy are 145.5 MPa Á g À1 Á cm 3 and 23.0%, respectively. The specific yield strength is the highest among all other reported RHEAs. The superior mechanical properties of the Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 RHEA arise from the solid solution strength and cross-slip of dislocations. The ultrahigh specific yield strength and superior strength-plasticity synergy may promote the applications of RHEAs.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The high-entropy alloys (HEAs) have recently attracted intensive research interests because of their exceptional lowtemperature fracture toughness, irradiation resistance and mechanical performance [1][2][3]. For face-centered cubic (FCC) HEAs with intrinsic low yield strength, precipitation strengthening is an effective way to enhance the yield strength at the expense of plasticity for the appropriate strength-plasticity synergy [4]. While body-centered cubic (BCC) HEAs possess the intrinsic high yield strength but inferior plasticity at ambient temperature, especially the Refractory HEAs (RHEAs) generally exhibit outstanding hightemperature strength [5]. Therefore, it is of scientific importance to improve the plasticity of RHEAs at ambient temperature.

In 2010, Senkov et al. firstly proposed and fabricated a series of RHEAs with excellent softening resistance for super hightemperature applications [6]. However, these reported RHEAs exhibit negligible tensile ductility at ambient temperature due to their high ductile-brittle transition temperature (higher than room temperature) [3,7]. Research efforts have been attempted to overcoming this shortcoming, and a high content of ductile metals, including Nb, Hf and Ta, have been added to RHEAs to ameliorate the tensile plasticity at ambient temperature [3,[8][9][10]. However, the alloy density increases significantly, which severely limits their applications. Therefore, developing ductile RHEAs with high specific strength is of scientific and practical significance for their applications [11][12][13].

In this work, the light metal Al was introduced into the refractory Ti 1.5 ZrNb alloy, and the ductile Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 RHEA was developed, which shows the excellent strength-plasticity synergy and the highest specific yield strength among the reported RHEAs. The microstructural origins for the superior mechanical properties of the Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 were investigated in-depth. The alloy design strategy in this work might promote the development and the practical applications of RHEAs.

div.head: Materials and methods
div.p: Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 was cast in vacuum melting furnace and solidified to the bulk sample with a size of 40 mm Â 15 mm Â 3.7 mm. The bulk sample was cold-rolled with a thickness reduction of ~62%. Then it was annealed at 800 °C for 1 h and air-cooled, and then annealed at 600 °C for 1 h and water quenched. The former is for https://doi.org/10.1016/j.matlet.2021.129428 0167-577X/Ó 2021 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

the recrystallization and the latter is for the formation of chemical short-rang orderings (SROs). Tensile samples with a gauge length of 14 mm and cross-section dimension of 2.5 mm Â 1.2 mm were obtained from the sample after annealing. The preparation process of transmission electron microscopy (TEM) samples is described elsewhere in details [14]. Microstructures of Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 were characterized by X-ray diffractometer (XRD; Rigaku D/max-2500PC) and Electron Backscatter Diffraction (EBSD; Tescan MIRA3). Tensile tests were conducted on a universal testing machine (Instron 5582) at a strain rate of 10 À3 s À1 . Necking morphology of the deformed samples were characterized by scanning electron microscope (SEM; XL30-FEG, Holland).

div.head: Results and discussion
div.p: Fig. 1a shows the XRD pattern of Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 after annealing, which has the single-phase body-centered cubic b-structure. This is because the b phase stability increases with increasing content of the b-stabilizer element of Nb [15], whose content is as high as ~26.3 at.% in the Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 . Al element (~7.9 at.% in Ti 1.5 -ZrNbAl 0.3 ) is completely dissolved in the Ti 1.5 ZrNb matrix after heat treatment according to the Al-Ti-Zr and Al-Nb-Ti ternary phase diagrams [16,17]. The TEM micrograph and the selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern in Fig. 1b further indicate that Ti 1.5 -ZrNbAl 0.3 is a disordered BCC structure without precipitation. The EBSD map in Fig. 1c shows the recrystallized grains of Ti 1.5 -ZrNbAl 0.3 , and the grain size is 24.4 lm ± 13.8 lm. The EDS mappings in Fig. 1d demonstrate that the components of Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 are distributed uniformly, but chemical SROs should exist at atomic scales.

The tensile stress-strain curve of Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 is shown in Fig. 2a. The yield strength of Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 are 876 ± 6 MPa, which is higher than most of FCC HEAs. The intrinsic high yield strength of Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 with single BCC phase may attribute to the strong chemical bonding inherited from the p-d hybrid orbital bonding between hybridization of p state of Al and d state of transition metals [7,10]. And the strong chemical bonding would promote the formation of SROs, which can affect the dislocation glide resistance, e.g., the classical Peierls-Nabarro resistance is closely related to atomic bonding [18]. The solid solution strengthening (SSS) is evaluated in Appendix A of Supplementary data and is only ~22.8 MPa, which is obviously trivial to account for the strengthening effect. Furthermore, there is also no precipitation in the current Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 . Therefore, the SROs may be the dominant strengthening mechanism of the Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 .

The fracture strain (e f ) of Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 is 23.0%, which exceeds the plasticity of most RHEAs as shown in Fig. 2a. There is a slight drop in flow stress after reaching the ultimate tensile strength, and then a stable plastic deformation plateau is maintained until fracture. The true stress-strain curve and strain hardening rate of Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 have been shown in Fig. 2b. The alloy underwent the strain softening firstly after yield, and then maintained inferior positive strain hardening rate before necking. Moreover, numerous dimpled structures on the fracture surface as shown in the inset of Fig. 2a. These dimples are characteristic of ductile fracture mode and exhibit the inherent plastic deformability of Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 .

Comparing the r ys /q versus e f properties with other plastic RHEAs [3,8,10,[19][20][21][22][23][24][25], the specific yield strength of Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 is 145.5 MPa g À1 cm 3 , which is the highest among all other RMPEAs as shown in Fig. 2c. Meanwhile, the r ys /q À e f synergy of Ti 1.5 -ZrNbAl 0.3 is also the best among all other RHEAs. The r ys (MPa), e f (%), q (g cm À3 ) and r ys /q (MPa g À1 cm 3 ) of RHEAs are listed in Table S1 in Appendix B of Supplementary data.

The two-beam condition bright-field TEM (BF-TEM) images with g = 1 À 1 0 and g = 1 À 0 1 of Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 are shown in Fig. 3, where the analytical areas are selected from necking regions after fracture. The well-defined dislocation walls composed by vast cell substructures are developed in the post-deformed Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 . These dislocation cell/walls are usually caused by cross-slip of screw dislocations in BCC metals, whereas plasticity is strongly influenced by cross-slip [14,23]. In addition, a high density of dislocation pinning and loops are obviously observed, which are marked by blue and pink dashed labels. And the enlarged images of dislocation pinning and loops have been shown in Fig. 3c andd, respectively. The dislocation pinning and loops also contribute to the durability for plastic deformation. Based on the TEM results, the plastic deformation of the Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 is dominated by wavy slip of dislocations. It is obvious that this dominated wavy slip and multiple dislocation interactions can enhance the strengthplasticity synergy effectively.

figure.head: Fig. 1 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 1. XRD pattern (a), TEM micrograph and SAED pattern (inset) (b), EBSD grain map (c), and EDS mappings (d) of Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 after annealing.

In summary, a novel refractory Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 HEA with a single BCC phase has been developed. This alloy exhibits a superior combination of high yield strength (876 MPa), large plasticity (23.0%), and the specific yield strength (145.5 MPa g À1 cm 3 )-plasticity synergy. The specific yield strength of Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 is the highest among all other RMPEAs. Strong chemical bonding and the resultant SROs are the intrinsic origins for the high specific yield strength. The dominated cross-slip and multiple dislocation interactions, which forms vast dislocation pinning, loops, cell/walls, account for the durable plastic deformability of the Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 . The current alloy design strategy of Ti 1.5 ZrNbAl 0.3 may promote the applications of RHEAs. Long Zhang: Conceptualization, Methodology, Funding acquisition, Supervision, Writing -original draft, Writing -review & editing. Zhengwang

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: This work was supported financially by the National Key Research and Development Program (2018YFB0703402), the Chinese Academy of Sciences (ZDBS-LY-JSC023), the Liao Ning Revitalization Talents Program (XLYC1802078, XLYC1807062), Liaoning Key Research and Development Program (2020JH2/10100013), and the Youth Innovation Promotion Association CAS.

div.head: Declaration of Competing Interest
div.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
